clinical_study.brief_title: Regulation of Craving in Internet Gamers
clinical_study.official_title: Regulation of Craving in Internet Gamers: Neural Mechanisms and tDCS Intervention

brief_summary.textblock: This project aims to investigate (1) the behavioral and neural mechanisms of regulation of craving in Internet gamers; (2) effects of tDCS over the dorsal lateral cortex on craving and regulation of craving in this population. This project will be conducted in Beijing, China, based on a large sample of Internet gamers.

primary_outcome.measure: Craving regulation ability changes after the tDCS intervention
primary_outcome.time_frame: The interval between two tDCS is about 1 week
primary_outcome.description: Craving regulation ability, as measured by self-reported score, can be improved by tDCS on the DLPFC versus tDCS on the motor area.

secondary_outcome.measure: fMRI brain activation before the tDCS intervention
secondary_outcome.description: The regulate condition can activate the DLPFC region compared with the look condition.

arm_group.description: Dorsolateral prefrontal cortex (DLPFC) target will be identified by the baseline fMRI study for regulation of craving. During the intervention, each participant will receive a transcranial direct current stimulation (tDCS) intervention on this DLPFC region.
Each participant will also receive a control tDCS intervention on the motor area of the brain, which is not directly related to regulation of craving.

intervention.description: Each participant will receive both tDCS on the DLPFC and tDCS on the motor area. The sequence of the interventions will be counterbalanced across participants, and the interval between two interventions is more than a week.

facility.name: State Key Laboratory of Cognitive Neuroscience and Learning, Beijing Normal University
